docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S the next Cancun. The label has stuck on Punta Cana. In the travel trade press. On the tongues of agents. Even in the popular press, it's all you hear about the formerly barren eastern tip of the Dominican Republic. That, and phrases like ''hot spot of the Caribbean'' and ''top emerging international destination.'' It's too bad, because Punta Cana and Cancun, in Mexico, couldn't be more different. Except maybe in their histories and, if a handful of major tour operators have their say, in their growth patterns.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the seventh edition of ''The Lives They Lived,'' the magazine's annual tribute to remarkable lives that ended over the course of the previous 12 months. Some years are defined by the famous figures whose passing unites the country and even the world. But this past year was perhaps more memorably defined by the passing of certain ideas: the eschatological promise of the Y2K bug, the supposed invincibility of the dot-com revolution, the limitless trajectory of Clinton-era prosperity, the pristine certainty of the electoral process. And the people whose stories united us were ones we'd never before heard of: the 17 victims of the U.S.S. Cole bombing; the 7 employees of Edgewater Technology, where Michael McDermott opened fire; the 118 sailors of the doomed Russian submarine, whose fading distress signals went unanswered as the world counted down their final days. In compiling this issue, we were drawn not necessarily to the best known or most accomplished, but to people whose stories represented an idea or embodied a moment. Many of the distinguished writers whose contributions follow had personal connections to their subjects. Lorrie Moore worked in the same department as Frederic Cassidy, the lexicographer, though she never got to know him. John le Carre had a longstanding friendship with Alec Guinness, who brought Smiley, the novelist's most famous character, to life. Oscar Hijuelos never forgot the day when, as a teenager, he saw Tito Puente perform. Sam Tanenhaus corresponded with Ella Goldberg Wolfe, the woman who grew up a Communist and died a Reaganite. And Michael Chabon was fascinated by Gene Kelly's younger brother because he was from Pittsburgh, a city to which Chabon paid tribute in his first novel. Most of us knew these people through their public profiles, if at all. But regardless of anyone's relationship to them, lives well lived provide rich fodder for all imaginations.
docs.abstract: New York Times Magazine pays tribute to 28 people (and one horse) who died in 2000 whose lives made a difference; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 1950's have never looked more elegant -- not to mention bright, shiny and new -- than in Robert Redford's QUIZ SHOW (1994), the story of the decade's television quiz show scandals as experienced by two very different contestants. Ralph Fiennes is glamorous and complex as Charles Van Doren, the gold-boy son and nephew of prominent academics who has qualms about accepting the answers in advance but talks himself into going along with the fix. John Turturro is equally complex as Herb Stempel, the less educated, less dashing outer-boroughs guy who is forced to take a fall, giving up the qui show's championship because his ''ratings have plateaued.'' Paul Scofield is outstanding as Van Doren's father. Paul Attanasio's script is so thoughtful and intelligent that you wonder how it ever made its way, unscathed, into a main stream film -- Thursday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

docs.lead_paragraph: Judi Dench was on vacation in Barbados a year or so ago when her daughter found a dog-eared copy of a book that some traveler had left behind in their hotel room. It was ''Chocolat'' by Joanne Harris. ''I read the book, and I enjoyed it enormously,'' Dame Judi said, speaking by phone from London. ''So then, when I was asked to be in the film, I said, 'Yes, absolutely,' even though I was to play an 80-year-old woman. Even that worked out well, though. It's actually quite nice to get out of makeup at the end of the day and look better on your way home than you did all day long. It's much nicer that way.''

docs.snippet: IT'S that time again: the silly cinematic season of proliferating 10-best lists, critics' polls and movie ads bloated with hyperbolic quotations, all aimed at creating ''Oscar buzz'' as the countdown begins for the Academy Awards on March 25. Once...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S that time again: the silly cinematic season of proliferating 10-best lists, critics' polls and movie ads bloated with hyperbolic quotations, all aimed at creating ''Oscar buzz'' as the countdown begins for the Academy Awards on March 25. Once again, after a year of producing largely dreary commercial product, Hollywood has put on its straightest face to pretend that all it has ever really cared about is quality. And once again it can point to a (very small) handful of films that almost justify the chest-thumping pomposity. Until early December almost everybody who cares about such things agreed that 2000 had been an artistic disappointment. But by New Year's the tide of negativity had begun to recede as the lists piled up in newspapers, magazines, on television and on the Internet, and all the usual adjectives were trotted out.

In the 1980's he produced five public television documentaries with grants from the federal government and nonprofit foundations. Millions saw his works. Critics praised him. He won an Oscar and a Peabody Award in 1991.
docs.abstract: Makers of television documentaries face crisis in financing from nonprofit sources; in mid-1990's Congress slashed money for arts, and private foundations tightened belts; financing problem has had profound effect on what kinds of documentaries are made, how they are made and where filmmakers go for money; both young filmmakers and seasoned veterans, such as Steven Okazaki, are finding it harder to crack public television and are turning away from grant applications and toward cheaper digital technology, backing from corporations, cable outlets and foreign networks; photos (M)
